perturbation.original_text:
Article 53
Directors shall be appointed for a term of four (4) years, provided that the
Party who has appointed a director may remove that director and appoint a
replacement at any time. A director may serve consecutive terms if reappointed
by the Party that originally appointed him/her. If a seat on the Board of
Directors is vacated by the retirement, resignation, disability or death of a
director or by the removal of such director by the Party who originally
appointed him/her, the Party who originally appointed such director shall
appoint a successor to serve out such director's term. At the time this Contract
is signed and each time a director is appointed or replaced, each Party shall
notify the other Party in writing of the names of its appointees or
replacements.
perturbation.changed_text:
Article 53
Directors shall be appointed for a term of four (4) years, unless the Board of Directors decides otherwise. The Party who has appointed a director may remove that director and appoint a replacement at its convenience, but the replacement must be approved by a majority vote of the entire Board. A director may serve consecutive terms if reappointed by the Party that originally appointed him/her. If a seat on the Board of Directors is vacated by the retirement, resignation, disability or death of a
director or by the removal of such director by the Party who originally
appointed him/her, the Board will decide if the seat should be filled and who should fill that vacancy. At the time this Contract
is signed and each time a director is appointed or replaced, there is no obligation of informing the other party of the name of the replacement.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces contradiction. The original text states that the appointing party can remove/replace the director anytime while the changed text mentions that the replacement is subject to the majority vote of the entire board, thus removing the right of the appointing party of direct appointment. Also the original states that it is a duty to notify the other party of the replacement name while that is taken away from the changed text. This creates uncertainty as to who has the final say in the appointments and whether any notification is required.

perturbation.original_text:
Article 80
Except as provided in Article 78, expatriate personnel and Chinese personnel in
the same position shall be treated equally and without discrimination.
perturbation.changed_text:
Article 80
Expatriate personnel may receive additional allowances and benefits not provided to Chinese personnel in similar positions. The specifics of these allowances will be determined by the CEO at their sole discretion.
perturbation.explanation: This directly contradicts the principle of equal treatment established in the original Article 80. By allowing additional allowances solely for expatriate staff, it introduces discrimination and could be seen as a breach of fair labor practices, creating potential disputes and uncertainty regarding compensation policies.

perturbation.original_text:
Article 96
Prior to and during the Contract Term, each Party has disclosed or may disclose
to the other Party, including without limitation through technology transfer or
license agreements, confidential and proprietary information and materials
concerning their respective businesses, financial condition, proprietary
technology, research and development, and other confidential matters.
Furthermore,
during the Contract Term, the Parties may obtain such confidential and
proprietary information concerning the Joint Venture Company and the Joint
Venture Company may obtain such confidential and proprietary information of the
Parties. Each of the Parties and the Joint Venture Company receiving all such
information as aforesaid (hereinafter referred to "Confidential Information")
shall, during the Contract Term, or during the term of the Joint Venture Company
and for two (2) years after the early termination or dissolution of the Joint
Venture Company prior to the expiration of the Contract Term:
 (1) maintain the confidentiality of such Confidential Information;
 and
 (2) not disclose it to any person or entity, except to their
 respective employees who need to know such Confidential
 Information to perform their work responsibilities.
perturbation.changed_text:
Article 96
Prior to and during the Contract Term, each Party has disclosed or may disclose
to the other Party, including without limitation through technology transfer or
license agreements, confidential and proprietary information and materials
concerning their respective businesses, financial condition, proprietary
technology, research and development, and other confidential matters.
Furthermore,
during the Contract Term, the Parties may obtain such confidential and
proprietary information concerning the Joint Venture Company and the Joint
Venture Company may obtain such confidential and proprietary information of the
Parties. Each of the Parties and the Joint Venture Company receiving all such
information as aforesaid (hereinafter referred to "Confidential Information")
shall, during the Contract Term, or during the term of the Joint Venture Company:
 (1) maintain the confidentiality of such Confidential Information, only if it is profitable to do so;
 and
 (2) may disclose it to any person or entity if it benefits them, whether or not such party needs to know such Confidential Information to perform their work responsibilities.
perturbation.explanation: By adding the clause "only if it is profitable to do so" the first part of the condition is contradicted. By saying "may disclose it to any person or entity if it benefits them" it negates the condition that they cannot disclose it.
